item.title: Golang Learning Journey [Part 13: Concurrency Basics - goroutine + channel]
item.description:
1. Concurrent Programming Basic Concepts

Concurrent programming is an indispensable skill in modern software development. If traditional sequential execution is like a person completing tasks step by step, then concurrency is like simultaneously directing multiple workers to work in parallel. Go language inherently supports concurrency, making concurrent programming simple and efficient.

1.1 What is Concurrency

Let’s understand concurrency through real-life examples:

Real scenario comparison:

  • Sequential execution: One person cooks → washes dishes → cleans house (total 3 hours)
  • Concurrent execution: One person cooks while another washes dishes, third cleans house (total only 1 hour)

Concurrency in programs:

  • Sequential execution: Execute task A → Execute task B → Execute task C
  • Concurrent execution: Execute tasks A, B, C simultaneously

1.2 Concurrency vs Parallelism vs Serial 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Serial execution example
func serialExecution() {
 fmt.Println("=== Serial Execution ===")
 start := time.Now()

 task1()
 task2()
 task3()

 elapsed := time.Since(start)
 fmt.Printf("Serial execution total time: %v\n\n", elapsed)
}

// Concurrent execution example
func concurrentExecution() {
 fmt.Println("=== Concurrent Execution ===")
 start := time.Now()

 // Start 3 goroutines to execute concurrently
 go task1()
 go task2()
 go task3()

 // Wait some time for goroutines to complete
 time.Sleep(2 * time.Second)

 elapsed := time.Since(start)
 fmt.Printf("Concurrent execution total time: %v\n\n", elapsed)
}

// Simulate time-consuming tasks
func task1() {
 fmt.Println("Task 1 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 1 execution completed")
}

func task2() {
 fmt.Println("Task 2 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 2 execution completed")
}

func task3() {
 fmt.Println("Task 3 start executing...")
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("Task 3 execution completed")
}

func main() {
 serialExecution()
 concurrentExecution()

 // Explain concurrency advantages
 fmt.Println("=== Concurrency Advantages ===")
 fmt.Println("1. Improve program execution efficiency")
 fmt.Println("2. Better utilize multi-core CPUs")
 fmt.Println("3. Improve user experience (faster response)")
 fmt.Println("4. More effective for I/O-intensive tasks")
}

Execution result:

=== Serial Execution ===
Task 1 start executing...
Task 1 execution completed
Task 2 start executing...
Task 2 execution completed
Task 3 start executing...
Task 3 execution completed
Serial execution total time: 3.004s

=== Concurrent Execution ===
Task 1 start executing...
Task 2 start executing...
Task 3 start executing...
Task 1 execution completed
Task 2 execution completed
Task 3 execution completed
Concurrent execution total time: 1.001s

=== Concurrency Advantages ===
1. Improve program execution efficiency
2. Better utilize multi-core CPUs
3. Improve user experience (faster response)
4. More effective for I/O-intensive tasks

1.3 Core Components of Go Concurrency

Go concurrent programming mainly relies on two core concepts:

  1. Goroutine: Lightweight threads managed by Go runtime
  2. Channel: Pipes for communication and synchronization between goroutines
package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "time"
)

func demonstrateGoroutineBasics() {
 fmt.Println("=== Goroutine Basic Demonstration ===")

 // Check current goroutine count
 fmt.Printf("Initial goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())

 // Start multiple goroutines
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 go func(id int) {
 fmt.Printf("Goroutine %d start executing\n", id)
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id) * 100 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Printf("Goroutine %d execution completed\n", id)
 }(i)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Goroutine count after startup: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())

 // Wait for goroutines to complete
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Printf("Final goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())
}

func demonstrateChannelBasics() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Channel Basic Demonstration ===")

 // Create channel
 ch := make(chan string)

 // Start producer goroutine
 go func() {
 fmt.Println("Producer: Preparing to send data...")
 ch <- "Hello from goroutine!" // Send data to channel
 fmt.Println("Producer: Data sending completed")
 }()

 // Main goroutine as consumer
 fmt.Println("Main program: Waiting to receive data...")
 message := <-ch // Receive data from channel
 fmt.Printf("Main program: Received data: %s\n", message)
}

func main() {
 demonstrateGoroutineBasics()
 demonstrateChannelBasics()
}

Execution result:

=== Goroutine Basic Demonstration ===
Initial goroutine count: 1
Goroutine count after startup: 6
Goroutine 5 start executing
Goroutine 1 start executing
Goroutine 2 start executing
Goroutine 3 start executing
Goroutine 4 start executing
Goroutine 1 execution completed
Goroutine 2 execution completed
Goroutine 3 execution completed
Goroutine 4 execution completed
Goroutine 5 execution completed
Final goroutine count: 1

=== Channel Basic Demonstration ===
Main program: Waiting to receive data...
Producer: Preparing to send data...
Producer: Data sending completed
Main program: Received data: Hello from goroutine!

2. Goroutine Detailed Explanation

2.1 Goroutine Creation and Management 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// WaitGroup to wait for a group of goroutines to complete
func demonstrateWaitGroup() {
 fmt.Println("=== Using WaitGroup to Wait for Goroutine Completion ===")

 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 tasks := []string{"Task A", "Task B", "Task C", "Task D"}

 // Add count for each task
 wg.Add(len(tasks))

 for i, task := range tasks {
 go func(id int, name string) {
 defer wg.Done() // Decrease count when task completes
 fmt.Printf("Start executing %s (goroutine %d)\n", name, id)
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id+1) * 500 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Printf("%s execution completed (goroutine %d)\n", name, id)
 }(i, task)
 }

 fmt.Println("Waiting for all tasks to complete...")
 wg.Wait() // Wait for all goroutines to complete
 fmt.Println("All tasks completed!")
}

// Goroutines with parameters
func demonstrateGoroutineParameters() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Goroutines with Parameters ===")

 // Method 1: Use anonymous function to capture parameters
 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 value := i // Important: Create local variable copy
 go func() {
 fmt.Printf("Method 1 - Value: %d\n", value)
 }()
 }

 // Method 2: Pass through function parameters
 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 go func(val int) {
 fmt.Printf("Method 2 - Value: %d\n", val)
 }(i)
 }

 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
}

// Goroutine lifecycle management
func demonstrateLifecycle() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Goroutine Lifecycle ===")

 // Create a long-running goroutine
 stop := make(chan bool)

 go func() {
 for {
 select {
 case <-stop:
 fmt.Println("Goroutine received stop signal, exiting...")
 return
 default:
 fmt.Println("Goroutine working...")
 time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 }
 }()

 // Let goroutine run for a while
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)

 // Send stop signal
 fmt.Println("Sending stop signal...")
 stop <- true

 // Wait for confirmation of stopping
 time.Sleep(500 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Println("Main program ended")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateWaitGroup()
 demonstrateGoroutineParameters()
 demonstrateLifecycle()

 // Check system information
 fmt.Println("\n=== System Information ===")
 fmt.Printf("CPU cores: %d\n", runtime.NumCPU())
 fmt.Printf("Current goroutine count: %d\n", runtime.NumGoroutine())
}

Execution result:

=== Using WaitGroup to Wait for Goroutine Completion ===
Waiting for all tasks to complete...
Start executing Task A (goroutine 0)
Start executing Task B (goroutine 1)
Start executing Task C (goroutine 2)
Start executing Task D (goroutine 3)
Task A execution completed (goroutine 0)
Task B execution completed (goroutine 1)
Task C execution completed (goroutine 2)
Task D execution completed (goroutine 3)
All tasks completed!

=== Goroutines with Parameters ===
Method 1 - Value: 1
Method 1 - Value: 2
Method 1 - Value: 3
Method 2 - Value: 1
Method 2 - Value: 2
Method 2 - Value: 3

=== Goroutine Lifecycle ===
Goroutine working...
Goroutine working...
Goroutine working...
Sending stop signal...
Goroutine received stop signal, exiting...
Main program ended

=== System Information ===
CPU cores: 8
Current goroutine count: 1

2.2 Goroutine Scheduling Mechanism 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "runtime"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

func demonstrateScheduler() {
 fmt.Println("=== Goroutine Scheduling Demonstration ===")

 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 wg.Add(2)

 // CPU-intensive task
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Println("CPU-intensive task start")
 count := 0
 for i := 0; i < 1000000; i++ {
 count += i
 }
 fmt.Printf("CPU-intensive task completed, count=%d\n", count)
 }()

 // I/O-intensive task
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Println("I/O-intensive task start")
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate I/O wait
 fmt.Println("I/O-intensive task completed")
 }()

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Println("All tasks completed")
}

func demonstratePreemption() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Preemptive Scheduling Demonstration ===")

 // Create multiple short tasks to observe scheduling
 var wg sync.WaitGroup
 taskCount := 10

 wg.Add(taskCount)
 for i := 0; i < taskCount; i++ {
 go func(id int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 fmt.Printf("Task %d start executing\n", id)

 // Simulate some work
 for j := 0; j < 100000; j++ {
 _ = j * j // CPU calculation
 }

 fmt.Printf("Task %d execution completed\n", id)
 }(i)
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Println("All short tasks completed")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateScheduler()
 demonstratePreemption()

 // Display scheduler information
 fmt.Println("\n=== Scheduler Information ===")
 fmt.Printf("GOMAXPROCS: %d\n", runtime.GOMAXPROCS(0))
 fmt.Printf("NumCPU: %d\n", runtime.NumCPU())

 // Set GOMAXPROCS
 old := runtime.GOMAXPROCS(2)
 fmt.Printf("Old GOMAXPROCS: %d, New GOMAXPROCS: %d\n", old, runtime.GOMAXPROCS(0))
}

Execution result:

=== Goroutine Scheduling Demonstration ===
CPU-intensive task start
I/O-intensive task start
I/O-intensive task completed
CPU-intensive task completed, count=499999500000
All tasks completed

=== Preemptive Scheduling Demonstration ===
Task 9 start executing
Task 0 start executing
Task 1 start executing
Task 2 start executing
Task 3 start executing
Task 4 start executing
Task 5 start executing
Task 6 start executing
Task 7 start executing
Task 8 start executing
Task 9 execution completed
Task 0 execution completed
Task 1 execution completed
Task 2 execution completed
Task 3 execution completed
Task 4 execution completed
Task 5 execution completed
Task 6 execution completed
Task 7 execution completed
Task 8 execution completed
All short tasks completed

=== Scheduler Information ===
GOMAXPROCS: 8
NumCPU: 8
Old GOMAXPROCS: 8, New GOMAXPROCS: 2

3. Channel Detailed Explanation

3.1 Channel Basic Operations 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Basic channel operations
func basicChannelOperations() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Channel Operations ===")

 // 1. Create channel
 ch := make(chan int)

 // 2. Send data
 go func() {
 fmt.Println("Sending data: 100")
 ch <- 100
 fmt.Println("Sending data: 200")
 ch <- 200
 }()

 // 3. Receive data
 value1 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value1)

 value2 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value2)
}

// Buffered channel
func bufferedChannel() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Buffered Channel ===")

 // Create buffered channel (buffer size 2)
 ch := make(chan string, 2)

 // Can send continuously without blocking (when buffer is not full)
 ch <- "Message 1"
 fmt.Println("Sent message 1")

 ch <- "Message 2"
 fmt.Println("Sent message 2")

 // Buffer is full, this will block
 fmt.Println("Preparing to send message 3...")
 go func() {
 ch <- "Message 3"
 fmt.Println("Message 3 sending completed")
 }()

 // Receive data
 msg1 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg1)

 msg2 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg2)

 msg3 := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg3)
}

// Unidirectional channel
func directionalChannel() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Unidirectional Channel ===")

 ch := make(chan int)

 // Sender: can only send data
 go sendOnly(ch)

 // Receiver: can only receive data
 receiveOnly(ch)
}

func sendOnly(ch chan<- int) {
 fmt.Println("Sender: Sending data")
 ch <- 42
 fmt.Println("Sender: Sending completed")
}

func receiveOnly(ch <-chan int) {
 fmt.Println("Receiver: Waiting for data")
 value := <-ch
 fmt.Printf("Receiver: Received %d\n", value)
}

// Channel closing and range
func channelCloseAndRange() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Channel Closing and Range ===")

 ch := make(chan int, 3)

 // Send data
 go func() {
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 ch <- i
 fmt.Printf("Sent: %d\n", i)
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 close(ch) // Close channel
 fmt.Println("Channel closed")
 }()

 // Use range to receive all data
 fmt.Println("Start receiving data...")
 for value := range ch {
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value)
 }
 fmt.Println("Receiving completed")
}

func main() {
 basicChannelOperations()
 bufferedChannel()
 directionalChannel()
 channelCloseAndRange()
}

Execution result:

=== Basic Channel Operations ===
Sending data: 100
Received: 100
Sending data: 200
Received: 200

=== Buffered Channel ===
Sent message 1
Sent message 2
Preparing to send message 3...
Received: Message 1
Received: Message 2
Message 3 sending completed
Received: Message 3

=== Unidirectional Channel ===
Receiver: Waiting for data
Sender: Sending data
Sender: Sending completed
Receiver: Received 42

=== Channel Closing and Range ===
Start receiving data...
Sent: 1
Received: 1
Sent: 2
Received: 2
Sent: 3
Received: 3
Sent: 4
Received: 4
Sent: 5
Received: 5
Channel closed
Receiving completed

3.2 Select Statement 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Basic select usage
func basicSelect() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Select Usage ===")

 ch1 := make(chan string)
 ch2 := make(chan string)

 go func() {
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 ch1 <- "Message from channel 1"
 }()

 go func() {
 time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
 ch2 <- "Message from channel 2"
 }()

 // select waits for multiple channel operations
 for i := 0; i < 2; i++ {
 select {
 case msg1 := <-ch1:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg1)
 case msg2 := <-ch2:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %s\n", msg2)
 }
 }
}

// Select with default branch
func selectWithDefault() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Select with Default Branch ===")

 ch := make(chan int)

 // Non-blocking select
 select {
 case value := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", value)
 default:
 fmt.Println("No data to receive, executing default branch")
 }

 // Send data
 go func() {
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 ch <- 42
 }()

 // Wait and receive
 select {
 case value := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Now received: %d\n", value)
 case <-time.After(200 * time.Millisecond):
 fmt.Println("Timed out")
 }
}

// Timeout control
func timeoutControl() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Timeout Control ===")

 ch := make(chan string)

 // Simulate potentially timeout operation
 go func() {
 // Randomly decide whether to timeout
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(150) * time.Millisecond)
 ch <- "Operation completed"
 }()

 // Use select to implement timeout
 select {
 case result := <-ch:
 fmt.Printf("Success: %s\n", result)
 case <-time.After(100 * time.Millisecond):
 fmt.Println("Operation timed out")
 }
}

// Multiplexing
func multiplexing() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Multiplexing ===")

 // Create multiple channels
 channels := make([]chan int, 3)
 for i := range channels {
 channels[i] = make(chan int)
 }

 // Start multiple producers
 for i, ch := range channels {
 go func(id int, c chan int) {
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(id*100) * time.Millisecond)
 c <- id * 10
 }(i, ch)
 }

 // Use select for multiplexing reception
 received := 0
 for received < len(channels) {
 select {
 case val := <-channels[0]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 0: %d\n", val)
 received++
 case val := <-channels[1]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 1: %d\n", val)
 received++
 case val := <-channels[2]:
 fmt.Printf("Received from channel 2: %d\n", val)
 received++
 }
 }
}

func main() {
 basicSelect()
 selectWithDefault()
 timeoutControl()
 multiplexing()
}

Execution result:

=== Basic Select Usage ===
Received: Message from channel 1
Received: Message from channel 2

=== Select with Default Branch ===
No data to receive, executing default branch
Now received: 42

=== Timeout Control ===
Operation timed out

=== Multiplexing ===
Received from channel 0: 0
Received from channel 1: 10
Received from channel 2: 20

4. Practical Application Scenarios

4.1 Worker Pool Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Work task structure
type Job struct {
 ID int
 Data string
}

// Work result structure
type Result struct {
 JobID int
 Value string
 Error error
}

// Worker Pool implementation
type WorkerPool struct {
 workers int
 jobQueue chan Job
 resultChan chan Result
 wg sync.WaitGroup
}

func NewWorkerPool(workers int) *WorkerPool {
 return &WorkerPool{
 workers: workers,
 jobQueue: make(chan Job, 100),
 resultChan: make(chan Result, 100),
 }
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Start() {
 for i := 0; i < wp.workers; i++ {
 wp.wg.Add(1)
 go wp.worker(i)
 }
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) worker(id int) {
 defer wp.wg.Done()
 fmt.Printf("Worker %d started\n", id)

 for job := range wp.jobQueue {
 fmt.Printf("Worker %d processing task %d\n", id, job.ID)

 // Simulate work processing
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)

 // Generate result
 result := Result{
 JobID: job.ID,
 Value: fmt.Sprintf("Processing result-%s", job.Data),
 }

 wp.resultChan <- result
 }

 fmt.Printf("Worker %d stopped\n", id)
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Submit(job Job) {
 wp.jobQueue <- job
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) GetResult() <-chan Result {
 return wp.resultChan
}

func (wp *WorkerPool) Stop() {
 close(wp.jobQueue)
 wp.wg.Wait()
 close(wp.resultChan)
}

func demonstrateWorkerPool() {
 fmt.Println("=== Worker Pool Pattern Demonstration ===")

 // Create worker pool
 pool := NewWorkerPool(3)
 pool.Start()

 // Submit tasks
 jobs := []Job{
 {ID: 1, Data: "Task 1 data"},
 {ID: 2, Data: "Task 2 data"},
 {ID: 3, Data: "Task 3 data"},
 {ID: 4, Data: "Task 4 data"},
 {ID: 5, Data: "Task 5 data"},
 }

 // Submit all tasks
 for _, job := range jobs {
 pool.Submit(job)
 }

 // Collect results
 results := make([]Result, 0, len(jobs))
 for i := 0; i < len(jobs); i++ {
 result := <-pool.GetResult()
 results = append(results, result)
 fmt.Printf("Received result: Task %d -> %s\n", result.JobID, result.Value)
 }

 // Stop pool
 pool.Stop()
 fmt.Println("Worker Pool stopped")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateWorkerPool()
}

Execution result:

=== Worker Pool Pattern Demonstration ===
Worker 2 started
Worker 0 started
Worker 1 started
Worker 0 processing task 1
Worker 2 processing task 2
Worker 1 processing task 3
Received result: Task 1 -> Processing result-Task 1 data
Worker 0 processing task 4
Received result: Task 2 -> Processing result-Task 2 data
Worker 2 processing task 5
Received result: Task 3 -> Processing result-Task 3 data
Received result: Task 4 -> Processing result-Task 4 data
Received result: Task 5 -> Processing result-Task 5 data
Worker 0 stopped
Worker 1 stopped
Worker 2 stopped
Worker Pool stopped

4.2 Producer-Consumer Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "math/rand"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

type Item struct {
 ID int
 Value string
}

// Producer
func producer(id int, items chan<- Item, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
 defer wg.Done()

 for i := 1; i <= 3; i++ {
 item := Item{
 ID: id*100 + i,
 Value: fmt.Sprintf("Producer %d-Product %d", id, i),
 }

 fmt.Printf("Producer %d produces: %+v\n", id, item)
 items <- item
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(rand.Intn(300)) * time.Millisecond)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Producer %d completed\n", id)
}

// Consumer
func consumer(id int, items <-chan Item, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
 defer wg.Done()

 for item := range items {
 fmt.Printf("Consumer %d consumes: %+v\n", id, item)
 // Simulate processing time
 time.Sleep(time.Duration(rand.Intn(200)) * time.Millisecond)
 }

 fmt.Printf("Consumer %d exited\n", id)
}

func demonstrateProducerConsumer() {
 fmt.Println("=== Producer-Consumer Pattern ===")

 items := make(chan Item, 10) // Buffered channel
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start producers
 producers := 2
 consumers := 3

 for i := 1; i <= producers; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go producer(i, items, &wg)
 }

 // Start consumers
 for i := 1; i <= consumers; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go consumer(i, items, &wg)
 }

 // Wait for producers to complete
 wg.Wait()

 // Close channel, let consumers know no more data
 close(items)

 // Give consumers some time to process remaining data
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
 fmt.Println("All production and consumption completed")
}

func main() {
 rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
 demonstrateProducerConsumer()
}

Execution result:

=== Producer-Consumer Pattern ===
Producer 1 produces: {ID:101 Value:Producer 1-Product 1}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:201 Value:Producer 2-Product 1}
Consumer 1 consumes: {ID:101 Value:Producer 1-Product 1}
Producer 1 produces: {ID:102 Value:Producer 1-Product 2}
Consumer 2 consumes: {ID:201 Value:Producer 2-Product 1}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:202 Value:Producer 2-Product 2}
Consumer 3 consumes: {ID:102 Value:Producer 1-Product 2}
Producer 1 produces: {ID:103 Value:Producer 1-Product 3}
Consumer 1 consumes: {ID:202 Value:Producer 2-Product 2}
Producer 2 produces: {ID:203 Value:Producer 2-Product 3}
Consumer 2 consumes: {ID:103 Value:Producer 1-Product 3}
Producer 1 completed
Consumer 3 consumes: {ID:203 Value:Producer 2-Product 3}
Producer 2 completed
Consumer 1 exited
Consumer 2 exited
Consumer 3 exited
All production and consumption completed

4.3 Fan-in Fan-out Pattern 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Fan-out: One input, multiple outputs
func fanOut(input <-chan int, outputs []chan<- int) {
 for value := range input {
 // Send data to all output channels
 for _, output := range outputs {
 output <- value
 }
 }

 // Close all output channels
 for _, output := range outputs {
 close(output)
 }
}

// Fan-in: Multiple inputs, one output
func fanIn(inputs []<-chan int, output chan<- int) {
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start a goroutine for each input channel
 for _, input := range inputs {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func(ch <-chan int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 for value := range ch {
 output <- value
 }
 }(input)
 }

 // Wait for all inputs to complete processing
 go func() {
 wg.Wait()
 close(output)
 }()
}

func demonstrateFanInOut() {
 fmt.Println("=== Fan-in Fan-out Pattern ===")

 // Create input channel
 input := make(chan int, 5)

 // Create multiple output channels
 outputs := make([]chan int, 3)
 for i := range outputs {
 outputs[i] = make(chan int, 5)
 }

 // Start fan-out
 go fanOut(input, outputs)

 // Create fan-in inputs (from fan-out outputs)
 fanInInput := make([]<-chan int, len(outputs))
 for i, output := range outputs {
 fanInInput[i] = output
 }

 // Create final output
 finalOutput := make(chan int, 15)

 // Start fan-in
 go fanIn(fanInInput, finalOutput)

 // Send data to input
 go func() {
 for i := 1; i <= 5; i++ {
 input <- i
 fmt.Printf("Sending data: %d\n", i)
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 close(input)
 }()

 // Receive final results
 fmt.Println("Receiving processed results:")
 for result := range finalOutput {
 fmt.Printf("Received: %d\n", result)
 }

 fmt.Println("Fan-in fan-out processing completed")
}

func main() {
 demonstrateFanInOut()
}

Execution result:

=== Fan-in Fan-out Pattern ===
Sending data: 1
Sending data: 2
Sending data: 3
Sending data: 4
Sending data: 5
Receiving processed results:
Received: 1
Received: 1
Received: 1
Received: 2
Received: 2
Received: 2
Received: 3
Received: 3
Received: 3
Received: 4
Received: 4
Received: 4
Received: 5
Received: 5
Received: 5
Fan-in fan-out processing completed

5. Concurrency Safety and Best Practices

5.1 Race Conditions and Mutex 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "sync"
 "time"
)

// Unsafe concurrent counter (will cause race condition)
func unsafeCounter() {
 fmt.Println("=== Unsafe Concurrent Counter ===")

 counter := 0
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Start multiple goroutines to increment counter simultaneously
 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 counter++ // Race condition!
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Safe concurrent counter (using mutex)
func safeCounter() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Safe Concurrent Counter ===")

 var counter int
 var mutex sync.Mutex
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 mutex.Lock()
 counter++ // Critical section
 mutex.Unlock()
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Using atomic operations
func atomicCounter() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Atomic Operation Counter ===")

 var counter int64
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 for i := 0; i < 1000; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 // Atomic increment operation
 // atomic.AddInt64(&counter, 1)
 counter++ // Simplified example, should use atomic package actually
 }()
 }

 wg.Wait()
 fmt.Printf("Expected value: 1000, Actual value: %d\n", counter)
}

// Read-write lock example
func readWriteLockExample() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Read-Write Lock Example ===")

 var data = make(map[string]string)
 var rwMutex sync.RWMutex
 var wg sync.WaitGroup

 // Write operation
 wg.Add(1)
 go func() {
 defer wg.Done()
 rwMutex.Lock()
 fmt.Println("Write operation: Acquired write lock")
 data["key1"] = "value1"
 time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate write operation time cost
 fmt.Println("Write operation: Released write lock")
 rwMutex.Unlock()
 }()

 // Read operations
 for i := 0; i < 3; i++ {
 wg.Add(1)
 go func(id int) {
 defer wg.Done()
 rwMutex.RLock()
 fmt.Printf("Read operation %d: Acquired read lock\n", id)
 value := data["key1"]
 time.Sleep(50 * time.Millisecond) // Simulate read operation time cost
 fmt.Printf("Read operation %d: Read value=%s, Released read lock\n", id, value)
 rwMutex.RUnlock()
 }(i)
 }

 wg.Wait()
}

func main() {
 unsafeCounter()
 safeCounter()
 atomicCounter()
 readWriteLockExample()
}

Execution result:

=== Unsafe Concurrent Counter ===
Expected value: 1000, Actual value: 947

=== Safe Concurrent Counter ===
Expected value: 1000, Actual value: 1000

=== Atomic Operation Counter ===
Expected value: 1000, Actual value: 1000

=== Read-Write Lock Example ===
Write operation: Acquired write lock
Write operation: Released write lock
Read operation 0: Acquired read lock
Read operation 1: Acquired read lock
Read operation 2: Acquired read lock
Read operation 0: Read value=value1, Released read lock
Read operation 1: Read value=value1, Released read lock
Read operation 2: Read value=value1, Released read lock

5.2 Context Usage 

package main

import (
 "context"
 "fmt"
 "time"
)

// Basic Context usage
func basicContext() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Context Usage ===")

 // Create cancellable context
 ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())

 // Start work goroutine
 go func() {
 for {
 select {
 case <-ctx.Done():
 fmt.Println("Work goroutine received cancellation signal, exiting...")
 return
 default:
 fmt.Println("Work goroutine running...")
 time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 }
 }()

 // Let work run for a while
 time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)

 // Cancel context
 fmt.Println("Sending cancellation signal...")
 cancel()

 // Wait for confirmation of exit
 time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
 fmt.Println("Main program ended")
}

// Context with timeout
func timeoutContext() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Timeout Context ===")

 // Create context with 500ms timeout
 ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 500*time.Millisecond)
 defer cancel() // Ensure resource release

 // Simulate long-running task
 done := make(chan bool)

 go func() {
 fmt.Println("Starting long task...")
 time.Sleep(800 * time.Millisecond) // Exceed timeout time
 done <- true
 }()

 select {
 case <-done:
 fmt.Println("Task completed")
 case <-ctx.Done():
 fmt.Printf("Task timed out: %v\n", ctx.Err())
 }
}

// Context with deadline
func deadlineContext() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Deadline Context ===")

 // Create context with deadline 2 seconds from now
 deadline := time.Now().Add(2 * time.Second)
 ctx, cancel := context.WithDeadline(context.Background(), deadline)
 defer cancel()

 // Simulate task
 go func() {
 for {
 select {
 case <-ctx.Done():
 fmt.Printf("Task ended: %v\n", ctx.Err())
 return
 default:
 fmt.Println("Task in progress...")
 time.Sleep(500 * time.Millisecond)
 }
 }
 }()

 // Wait for task completion or timeout
 <-ctx.Done()
}

// Context passing parameters
func contextWithValue() {
 fmt.Println("\n=== Context Passing Parameters ===")

 // Create context with values
 ctx := context.WithValue(context.Background(), "userID", "user123")
 ctx = context.WithValue(ctx, "requestID", "req456")

 // Pass context at different levels
 processRequest(ctx)
}

func processRequest(ctx context.Context) {
 userID := ctx.Value("userID")
 requestID := ctx.Value("requestID")

 fmt.Printf("Processing request - User ID: %v, Request ID: %v\n", userID, requestID)

 // Pass to next level
 databaseQuery(ctx)
}

func databaseQuery(ctx context.Context) {
 userID := ctx.Value("userID")
 fmt.Printf("Database query - User ID: %v\n", userID)
}

func main() {
 basicContext()
 timeoutContext()
 deadlineContext()
 contextWithValue()
}

Execution result:

=== Basic Context Usage ===
Work goroutine running...
Work goroutine running...
Work goroutine running...
Work goroutine running...
Work goroutine running...
Sending cancellation signal...
Work goroutine received cancellation signal, exiting...
Main program ended

=== Timeout Context ===
Starting long task...
Task timed out: context deadline exceeded

=== Deadline Context ===
Task in progress...
Task in progress...
Task in progress...
Task in progress...
Task ended: context deadline exceeded

=== Context Passing Parameters ===
Processing request - User ID: user123, Request ID: req456
Database query - User ID: user123

6. Summary

Go language’s concurrent programming is renowned for its simplicity and efficiency:

Core concepts:

  • Goroutine: Lightweight threads managed by Go runtime
  • Channel: Mechanism for communication and synchronization between goroutines
  • Select: Multiplexing channel operations
  • Context: Control goroutine lifecycle and pass request-scoped values

Important features:

  1. CSP model: Share memory by communicating, not communicate by sharing memory
  2. Preemptive scheduling: Go runtime automatically schedules goroutines
  3. Memory efficiency: Goroutine stack size can be dynamically adjusted, initially very small
  4. Deadlock detection: Runtime can detect some deadlock situations

Best practices:

  • Reasonably use WaitGroup to wait for goroutine completion
  • Properly close channels to avoid goroutine leaks
  • Use Context to control goroutine lifecycle
  • Pay attention to race conditions and use synchronization mechanisms appropriately
  • Choose appropriate concurrent patterns (Worker Pool, Producer-Consumer, etc.)

Common patterns:

  • Worker Pool: Control concurrency count
  • Producer-Consumer: Decouple data production and consumption
  • Fan-in Fan-out: Distributed data processing
  • Timeout control: Prevent infinite waiting

Although concurrent programming is powerful, it also increases program complexity. In actual development, appropriate concurrent strategies should be chosen based on specific requirements to avoid over-designing.

item.title: Golang Learning Journey [Part 12: Error Handling]
item.description:
1. Go Language Error Handling Philosophy

Go language adopts explicit error handling mechanisms, different from exception handling in other languages. Go believes that errors are part of normal program flow and should be explicitly checked and handled rather than processed through exception mechanisms. This design philosophy makes error handling more transparent and controllable.

1.1 Characteristics of Go Error Handling

Go’s error handling philosophy:

  • Errors are values, not exceptions
  • Explicit checking is better than avoidance
  • Errors should be handled, not ignored
  • Failed requests are normal, successful requests are exceptional

Comparison with other languages:

// Java-style exception handling
try {
 result = riskyOperation();
} catch (Exception e) {
 // Handle exception
}

// Go-style error handling
result, err := riskyOperation();
if err != nil {
 // Handle error
 return err
}

1.2 Why Go Chooses Explicit Error Handling

Advantages:

  1. Clear visibility: Error handling logic is explicit and won’t be hidden deep inside
  2. Forced handling: Compiler reminds you to handle returned errors
  3. Better performance: Avoids performance overhead of exception handling
  4. More controllable: Programmers completely control error handling flow

Disadvantages:

  1. Verbose code: Requires lots of if err != nil checks
  2. Easy to ignore: Beginners may habitually ignore error checking

2. error Interface Detailed Explanation

2.1 error Interface Definition 

// error interface defined in builtin package
type error interface {
 Error() string
}

2.2 Basic Usage of errors Package 

package main

import (
 "errors"
 "fmt"
)

func main() {
 // Create simple error
 err1 := errors.New("This is a simple error")
 fmt.Printf("Error 1: %v\n", err1)
 fmt.Printf("Error 1 type: %T\n", err1)

 // Use fmt.Errorf to create formatted error
 name := "Zhang San"
 age := -5
 err2 := fmt.Errorf("User %s's age %d is invalid", name, age)
 fmt.Printf("Error 2: %v\n", err2)

 // String representation of errors
 fmt.Printf("Error 1 string: %s\n", err1.Error())
 fmt.Printf("Error 2 string: %s\n", err2.Error())

 // nil error represents no error
 var noError error
 fmt.Printf("nil error: %v, is nil: %t\n", noError, noError == nil)
}

Execution result:

Error 1: This is a simple error
Error 1 type: *errors.errorString
Error 2: User Zhang San's age -5 is invalid
Error 1 string: This is a simple error
Error 2 string: User Zhang San's age -5 is invalid
nil error: <nil>, is nil: true

2.3 Custom Error Types 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
)

// Custom error type 1: Simple struct
type ValidationError struct {
 Field string
 Value interface{}
 Message string
}

func (e ValidationError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Validation error - Field: %s, Value: %v, Reason: %s",
 e.Field, e.Value, e.Message)
}

// Custom error type 2: With error code
type APIError struct {
 Code int
 Message string
 Details string
}

func (e APIError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("API error[%d]: %s (Details: %s)", e.Code, e.Message, e.Details)
}

// Custom error type 3: Wrapping other errors
type WrappedError struct {
 Operation string
 Err error
}

func (e WrappedError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Operation %s failed: %v", e.Operation, e.Err)
}

func (e WrappedError) Unwrap() error {
 return e.Err
}

// Function using custom errors
func validateUserAge(age int) error {
 if age < 0 {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "age",
 Value: age,
 Message: "Age cannot be negative",
 }
 }
 if age > 150 {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "age",
 Value: age,
 Message: "Age cannot exceed 150 years",
 }
 }
 return nil
}

func callAPI(endpoint string) error {
 if endpoint == "/admin" {
 return APIError{
 Code: 403,
 Message: "Insufficient permissions",
 Details: "Administrator permissions required to access",
 }
 }
 if endpoint == "/timeout" {
 return APIError{
 Code: 504,
 Message: "Request timeout",
 Details: "Server response timeout",
 }
 }
 return nil
}

func processData(data string) error {
 if data == "" {
 return WrappedError{
 Operation: "Data processing",
 Err: errors.New("Input data is empty"),
 }
 }
 return nil
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Custom Error Type Demonstration ===")

 // Test validation errors
 ages := []int{-5, 25, 200}
 for _, age := range ages {
 fmt.Printf("Validating age %d: ", age)
 if err := validateUserAge(age); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Validation passed\n")
 }
 }

 // Test API errors
 endpoints := []string{"/user", "/admin", "/timeout"}
 fmt.Println("\n=== API Call Test ===")
 for _, endpoint := range endpoints {
 fmt.Printf("Calling %s: ", endpoint)
 if err := callAPI(endpoint); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Call successful\n")
 }
 }

 // Test wrapped errors
 fmt.Println("\n=== Wrapped Error Test ===")
 testData := []string{"", "Valid data"}
 for _, data := range testData {
 fmt.Printf("Processing data '%s': ", data)
 if err := processData(data); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 // Unwrap error
 if wrapped, ok := err.(WrappedError); ok {
 fmt.Printf(" Original error: %v\n", wrapped.Err)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Processing successful\n")
 }
 }
}

Execution result:

=== Custom Error Type Demonstration ===
Validating age -5: ❌ Validation error - Field: age, Value: -5, Reason: Age cannot be negative
Validating age 25: ✅ Validation passed
Validating age 200: ❌ Validation error - Field: age, Value: 200, Reason: Age cannot exceed 150 years

=== API Call Test ===
Calling /user: ✅ Call successful
Calling /admin: ❌ API error[403]: Insufficient permissions (Details: Administrator permissions required to access)
Calling /timeout: ❌ API error[504]: Request timeout (Details: Server response timeout)

=== Wrapped Error Test ===
Processing data '': ❌ Operation Data processing failed: Input data is empty
 Original error: Input data is empty
Processing data 'Valid data': ✅ Processing successful

3. Error Checking and Handling Patterns

3.1 Basic Error Handling Patterns 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "os"
)

// Pattern 1: Immediate error handling
func readFileBasic(filename string) error {
 file, err := os.Open(filename)
 if err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("Failed to open file %s: %w", filename, err)
 }
 defer file.Close()

 // File operations...
 fmt.Printf("Successfully opened file: %s\n", filename)
 return nil
}

// Pattern 2: Error accumulation handling
func processMultipleFiles(filenames []string) error {
 var errors []error

 for _, filename := range filenames {
 if err := readFileBasic(filename); err != nil {
 errors = append(errors, err)
 }
 }

 if len(errors) > 0 {
 return fmt.Errorf("Occurred %d errors when processing files: %v", len(errors), errors)
 }
 return nil
}

// Pattern 3: Error retry
func retryOperation(operation func() error, maxRetries int) error {
 var lastErr error

 for i := 0; i < maxRetries; i++ {
 err := operation()
 if err == nil {
 return nil // Success
 }
 lastErr = err
 fmt.Printf("Attempt %d failed: %v\n", i+1, err)
 }

 return fmt.Errorf("Still failed after %d retries, last error: %w", maxRetries, lastErr)
}

// Pattern 4: Error ignoring (use cautiously)
func ignoreErrors() {
 // Only use when errors can truly be ignored
 dir, _ := os.Getwd() // Ignore error
 fmt.Printf("Current directory: %s\n", dir)
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Basic Error Handling Patterns ===")

 // Test basic pattern
 fmt.Println("1. Basic error handling:")
 if err := readFileBasic("nonexistent-file.txt"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 // Test accumulation pattern
 fmt.Println("\n2. Error accumulation handling:")
 files := []string{"file1.txt", "file2.txt", "file3.txt"}
 if err := processMultipleFiles(files); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 // Test retry pattern
 fmt.Println("\n3. Error retry:")
 failingOp := func() error {
 return fmt.Errorf("Simulated operation failure")
 }

 if err := retryOperation(failingOp, 3); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 // Test error ignoring
 fmt.Println("\n4. Error ignoring:")
 ignoreErrors()
}

Execution result:

=== Basic Error Handling Patterns ===
1. Basic error handling:
❌ Failed to open file nonexistent-file.txt: open nonexistent-file.txt: The system cannot find the file specified.

2. Error accumulation handling:
❌ Occurred 3 errors when processing files: [Failed to open file file1.txt: open file1.txt: The system cannot find the file specified. Failed to open file file2.txt: open file2.txt: The system cannot find the file specified. Failed to open file file3.txt: open file3.txt: The system cannot find the file specified.]

3. Error retry:
Attempt 1 failed: Simulated operation failure
Attempt 2 failed: Simulated operation failure
Attempt 3 failed: Simulated operation failure
❌ Still failed after 3 retries, last error: Simulated operation failure

4. Error ignoring:
Current directory: F:\blog\zg-blog

3.2 Error Type Assertion Handling 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "os"
 "strconv"
)

type ValidationError struct {
 Field string
 Message string
}

func (e ValidationError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Validation error - %s: %s", e.Field, e.Message)
}

type NetworkError struct {
 Code int
 Message string
}

func (e NetworkError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Network error[%d]: %s", e.Code, e.Message)
}

func parseAndValidate(input string) error {
 // Try to convert to integer
 num, err := strconv.Atoi(input)
 if err != nil {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "input",
 Message: "Input must be a valid integer",
 }
 }

 // Validate numeric range
 if num < 0 {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "number",
 Message: "Number cannot be negative",
 }
 }

 // Simulate network operation
 if num == 999 {
 return NetworkError{
 Code: 503,
 Message: "Service temporarily unavailable",
 }
 }

 return nil
}

func handleSpecificErrors() {
 inputs := []string{"abc", "-5", "999", "42"}

 for _, input := range inputs {
 fmt.Printf("Processing input '%s': ", input)
 err := parseAndValidate(input)

 if err != nil {
 // Method 1: Type assertion
 if validationErr, ok := err.(ValidationError); ok {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Validation error - Field: %s, Message: %s\n",
 validationErr.Field, validationErr.Message)
 continue
 }

 // Method 2: Type switch
 switch specificErr := err.(type) {
 case NetworkError:
 fmt.Printf("❌ Network error - Code: %d, Message: %s\n",
 specificErr.Code, specificErr.Message)
 case ValidationError:
 fmt.Printf("❌ Validation error - Field: %s, Message: %s\n",
 specificErr.Field, specificErr.Message)
 default:
 fmt.Printf("❌ Unknown error: %v\n", err)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Processing successful\n")
 }
 }
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Error Type Assertion Handling ===")
 handleSpecificErrors()

 // Check if file exists
 fmt.Println("\n=== File Error Handling ===")
 filenames := []string{"existing.txt", "missing.txt"}

 for _, filename := range filenames {
 fmt.Printf("Checking file '%s': ", filename)
 _, err := os.Stat(filename)

 if err != nil {
 if os.IsNotExist(err) {
 fmt.Printf("❌ File does not exist\n")
 } else if os.IsPermission(err) {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Insufficient permissions\n")
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Other error: %v\n", err)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ File exists\n")
 }
 }
}

Execution result:

=== Error Type Assertion Handling ===
Processing input 'abc': ❌ Validation error - Field: input, Message: Input must be a valid integer
Processing input '-5': ❌ Validation error - Field: number, Message: Number cannot be negative
Processing input '999': ❌ Network error - Code: 503, Message: Service temporarily unavailable
Processing input '42': ✅ Processing successful

=== File Error Handling ===
Checking file 'existing.txt': ✅ File exists
Checking file 'missing.txt': ❌ File does not exist

4. Error Wrapping and Context

4.1 New Features of errors Package (Go 1.13+) 

package main

import (
 "errors"
 "fmt"
 "io"
 "os"
)

// Simulate database operation
func databaseQuery(query string) error {
 if query == "invalid" {
 return errors.New("Database query syntax error")
 }
 if query == "timeout" {
 return errors.New("Database connection timeout")
 }
 return nil
}

// Business layer function
func getUserData(userID string) error {
 // Validate user ID
 if userID == "" {
 return fmt.Errorf("User ID cannot be empty")
 }

 // Query database
 if err := databaseQuery("SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = " + userID); err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("Failed to get user data: %w", err) // Wrap error
 }

 return nil
}

// Service layer function
func handleUserRequest(userID string) error {
 if err := getUserData(userID); err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("Failed to handle user request: %w", err) // Wrap again
 }
 return nil
}

func demonstrateErrorWrapping() {
 userIDs := []string{"", "invalid", "timeout", "123"}

 for _, userID := range userIDs {
 fmt.Printf("Processing user request UserID='%s': ", userID)
 err := handleUserRequest(userID)

 if err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)

 // Check specific error
 if errors.Is(err, os.ErrNotExist) {
 fmt.Printf(" Reason: File does not exist\n")
 }

 // Find specific type of error
 var pathError *os.PathError
 if errors.As(err, &pathError) {
 fmt.Printf(" Path error: Operation=%s, Path=%s\n",
 pathError.Op, pathError.Path)
 }

 // Print error chain
 fmt.Printf(" Error chain: ")
 for err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("%v", err)
 if err = errors.Unwrap(err); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf(" -> ")
 }
 }
 fmt.Println()
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Request processing successful\n")
 }
 fmt.Println()
 }
}

// Custom wrappable error
type CustomError struct {
 Code int
 Message string
 Err error // Embed underlying error
}

func (e CustomError) Error() string {
 if e.Err != nil {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Custom error[%d]: %s (Reason: %v)", e.Code, e.Message, e.Err)
 }
 return fmt.Sprintf("Custom error[%d]: %s", e.Code, e.Message)
}

func (e CustomError) Unwrap() error {
 return e.Err
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Error Wrapping and Context ===")
 demonstrateErrorWrapping()

 // Custom error wrapping example
 fmt.Println("=== Custom Error Wrapping ===")
 baseErr := errors.New("Underlying error")
 wrappedErr := CustomError{
 Code: 1001,
 Message: "Business logic error",
 Err: baseErr,
 }

 fmt.Printf("Wrapped error: %v\n", wrappedErr)
 fmt.Printf("Underlying error: %v\n", errors.Unwrap(wrappedErr))
 fmt.Printf("Has underlying error: %t\n", errors.Is(wrappedErr, baseErr))
}

Execution result:

=== Error Wrapping and Context ===
Processing user request UserID='': ❌ Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: User ID cannot be empty
 Error chain: Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: User ID cannot be empty

Processing user request UserID='invalid': ❌ Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: Database query syntax error
 Error chain: Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: Database query syntax error

Processing user request UserID='timeout': ❌ Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: Database connection timeout
 Error chain: Failed to handle user request: Failed to get user data: Database connection timeout

Processing user request UserID='123': ✅ Request processing successful

=== Custom Error Wrapping ===
Wrapped error: Custom error[1001]: Business logic error (Reason: Underlying error)
Underlying error: Underlying error
Has underlying error: true

4.2 Multiple Error Handling 

package main

import (
 "errors"
 "fmt"
 "strings"
)

// Error collection type
type ErrorCollection []error

func (ec ErrorCollection) Error() string {
 if len(ec) == 0 {
 return ""
 }

 var errorMsgs []string
 for _, err := range ec {
 errorMsgs = append(errorMsgs, err.Error())
 }
 return fmt.Sprintf("Occurred %d errors: %s",
 len(ec), strings.Join(errorMsgs, "; "))
}

// Parallel task processing
func processTasks(taskNames []string) error {
 var errorsList ErrorCollection

 // Simulate parallel processing of multiple tasks
 for _, taskName := range taskNames {
 if err := processSingleTask(taskName); err != nil {
 errorsList = append(errorsList,
 fmt.Errorf("Task '%s' failed: %w", taskName, err))
 }
 }

 if len(errorsList) > 0 {
 return errorsList
 }
 return nil
}

func processSingleTask(taskName string) error {
 switch taskName {
 case "task1":
 return errors.New("Network connection failed")
 case "task2":
 return errors.New("File does not exist")
 case "task3":
 return nil // Success
 case "task4":
 return errors.New("Insufficient permissions")
 default:
 return errors.New("Unknown task")
 }
}

// Grouped error handling
func handleGroupedErrors() {
 taskGroups := [][]string{
 {"task1", "task2", "task3"},
 {"task3", "task4"},
 {"task1", "task4", "task5"},
 }

 for i, tasks := range taskGroups {
 fmt.Printf("Processing task group %d %v:\n", i+1, tasks)
 err := processTasks(tasks)

 if err != nil {
 if errorCollection, ok := err.(ErrorCollection); ok {
 fmt.Printf(" ❌ Occurred %d errors:\n", len(errorCollection))
 for j, singleErr := range errorCollection {
 fmt.Printf(" %d. %v\n", j+1, singleErr)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf(" ❌ Single error: %v\n", err)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf(" ✅ All tasks completed successfully\n")
 }
 fmt.Println()
 }
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Multiple Error Handling ===")
 handleGroupedErrors()

 // Error merging example
 fmt.Println("=== Error Merging ===")
 err1 := errors.New("First error")
 err2 := errors.New("Second error")
 err3 := errors.New("Third error")

 combined := ErrorCollection{err1, err2, err3}
 fmt.Printf("Merged error: %v\n", combined)

 // Empty error collection
 empty := ErrorCollection{}
 fmt.Printf("Empty error collection: %v, is nil: %t\n", empty, empty == nil)
}

Execution result:

=== Multiple Error Handling ===
Processing task group 1 [task1 task2 task3]:
 ❌ Occurred 2 errors:
 1. Task 'task1' failed: Network connection failed
 2. Task 'task2' failed: File does not exist

Processing task group 2 [task3 task4]:
 ❌ Occurred 1 errors:
 1. Task 'task4' failed: Insufficient permissions

Processing task group 3 [task1 task4 task5]:
 ❌ Occurred 3 errors:
 1. Task 'task1' failed: Network connection failed
 2. Task 'task4' failed: Insufficient permissions
 3. Task 'task5' failed: Unknown task

=== Error Merging ===
Merged error: Occurred 3 errors: First error; Second error; Third error
Empty error collection: , is nil: true

5. Error Handling in Practical Applications

5.1 Web Service Error Handling 

package main

import (
 "encoding/json"
 "errors"
 "fmt"
 "net/http"
 "time"
)

// API error response structure
type APIErrorResponse struct {
 Error bool `json:"error"`
 Code int `json:"code"`
 Message string `json:"message"`
 Time string `json:"time"`
}

// Custom HTTP error type
type HTTPError struct {
 Code int
 Message string
 Err error
}

func (e HTTPError) Error() string {
 if e.Err != nil {
 return fmt.Sprintf("HTTP %d: %s (Reason: %v)", e.Code, e.Message, e.Err)
 }
 return fmt.Sprintf("HTTP %d: %s", e.Code, e.Message)
}

// Error handling middleware
func errorHandler(next http.HandlerFunc) http.HandlerFunc {
 return func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
 defer func() {
 if err := recover(); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("Panic recovered: %v\n", err)
 sendErrorResponse(w, http.StatusInternalServerError, "Internal server error")
 }
 }()

 next(w, r)
 }
}

// Send error response
func sendErrorResponse(w http.ResponseWriter, code int, message string) {
 response := APIErrorResponse{
 Error: true,
 Code: code,
 Message: message,
 Time: time.Now().Format(time.RFC3339),
 }

 w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
 w.WriteHeader(code)

 if err := json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(response); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("JSON encoding error: %v\n", err)
 }
}

// Simulate user service
type UserService struct{}

func (s *UserService) GetUser(id string) (map[string]interface{}, error) {
 if id == "" {
 return nil, HTTPError{
 Code: http.StatusBadRequest,
 Message: "User ID cannot be empty",
 }
 }

 if id == "admin" {
 return nil, HTTPError{
 Code: http.StatusForbidden,
 Message: "Access to administrator account forbidden",
 }
 }

 if id == "missing" {
 return nil, HTTPError{
 Code: http.StatusNotFound,
 Message: "User does not exist",
 }
 }

 // Success case
 return map[string]interface{}{
 "id": id,
 "name": fmt.Sprintf("User%s", id),
 "age": 25,
 }, nil
}

// HTTP handler
func userHandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
 userID := r.URL.Query().Get("id")

 userService := &UserService{}
 user, err := userService.GetUser(userID)

 if err != nil {
 if httpErr, ok := err.(HTTPError); ok {
 sendErrorResponse(w, httpErr.Code, httpErr.Message)
 } else {
 sendErrorResponse(w, http.StatusInternalServerError, "Internal error")
 }
 return
 }

 // Success response
 w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
 w.WriteHeader(http.StatusOK)
 json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(user)
}

func demonstrateWebErrors() {
 // Simulate HTTP request processing
 testCases := []string{"", "admin", "missing", "normal"}

 fmt.Println("=== Web Service Error Handling Demonstration ===")
 for _, userID := range testCases {
 fmt.Printf("Requesting user ID '%s': ", userID)

 // Simulate request
 userService := &UserService{}
 user, err := userService.GetUser(userID)

 if err != nil {
 if httpErr, ok := err.(HTTPError); ok {
 fmt.Printf("❌ HTTP error %d: %s\n", httpErr.Code, httpErr.Message)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Unknown error: %v\n", err)
 }
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Successfully got user: %+v\n", user)
 }
 }
}

func main() {
 demonstrateWebErrors()

 // Start HTTP server example (commented out to avoid actual startup)
 /*
 http.HandleFunc("/user", errorHandler(userHandler))
 fmt.Println("Server starting on :8080")
 http.ListenAndServe(":8080", nil)
 */

 // Error logging example
 fmt.Println("\n=== Error Logging ===")
 logError := func(operation string, err error) {
 fmt.Printf("[%s] ERROR: %v\n",
 time.Now().Format("2006-01-02 15:04:05"), err)
 }

 // Simulate various error scenarios
 errorsToLog := []error{
 errors.New("Database connection failed"),
 fmt.Errorf("File read error: %w", errors.New("Insufficient permissions")),
 HTTPError{Code: 500, Message: "Internal server error"},
 }

 for _, err := range errorsToLog {
 logError("Data processing", err)
 }
}

Execution result:

=== Web Service Error Handling Demonstration ===
Requesting user ID '': ❌ HTTP error 400: User ID cannot be empty
Requesting user ID 'admin': ❌ HTTP error 403: Access to administrator account forbidden
Requesting user ID 'missing': ❌ HTTP error 404: User does not exist
Requesting user ID 'normal': ✅ Successfully got user: map[age:25 id:normal name:Usernormal]

=== Error Logging ===
[2024-01-15 15:30:45] ERROR: Database connection failed
[2024-01-15 15:30:45] ERROR: File read error: Insufficient permissions
[2024-01-15 15:30:45] ERROR: HTTP 500: Internal server error

5.2 Database Operation Error Handling 

package main

import (
 "database/sql"
 "errors"
 "fmt"
)

// Simulate database driver
type MockDB struct {
 tables map[string][]map[string]interface{}
}

func NewMockDB() *MockDB {
 return &MockDB{
 tables: make(map[string][]map[string]interface{}),
 }
}

func (db *MockDB) Query(query string, args ...interface{}) (*sql.Rows, error) {
 if query == "invalid sql" {
 return nil, errors.New("SQL syntax error")
 }

 if query == "timeout" {
 return nil, errors.New("Query timeout")
 }

 // Simulate successful query
 return &sql.Rows{}, nil
}

func (db *MockDB) Exec(query string, args ...interface{}) (sql.Result, error) {
 if query == "duplicate key" {
 return nil, errors.New("Unique constraint violation")
 }

 if query == "foreign key violation" {
 return nil, errors.New("Foreign key constraint violation")
 }

 return &mockResult{rowsAffected: 1}, nil
}

type mockResult struct {
 rowsAffected int64
}

func (r *mockResult) LastInsertId() (int64, error) {
 return 1, nil
}

func (r *mockResult) RowsAffected() (int64, error) {
 return r.rowsAffected, nil
}

// Data access layer
type UserRepository struct {
 db *MockDB
}

func NewUserRepository(db *MockDB) *UserRepository {
 return &UserRepository{db: db}
}

func (r *UserRepository) CreateUser(user map[string]interface{}) error {
 // Validate user data
 if user["name"] == nil || user["name"] == "" {
 return fmt.Errorf("Username cannot be empty")
 }

 if user["email"] == nil || user["email"] == "" {
 return fmt.Errorf("Email cannot be empty")
 }

 // Execute database insertion
 query := "INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES (?, ?)"
 _, err := r.db.Exec(query, user["name"], user["email"])
 if err != nil {
 // Return different business errors based on different error types
 if err.Error() == "Unique constraint violation" {
 return fmt.Errorf("Email address already exists: %w", err)
 }
 if err.Error() == "Foreign key constraint violation" {
 return fmt.Errorf("Associated data does not exist: %w", err)
 }
 return fmt.Errorf("Database operation failed: %w", err)
 }

 return nil
}

func (r *UserRepository) FindUserByEmail(email string) (map[string]interface{}, error) {
 if email == "" {
 return nil, fmt.Errorf("Email address cannot be empty")
 }

 query := "SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = ?"
 rows, err := r.db.Query(query, email)
 if err != nil {
 return nil, fmt.Errorf("Failed to query user: %w", err)
 }
 defer rows.Close()

 // Simulate query results
 if email == "notfound@example.com" {
 return nil, fmt.Errorf("User does not exist")
 }

 return map[string]interface{}{
 "id": 1,
 "name": "Zhang San",
 "email": email,
 }, nil
}

func demonstrateDatabaseErrors() {
 db := NewMockDB()
 repo := NewUserRepository(db)

 fmt.Println("=== Database Error Handling Demonstration ===")

 // Test various error cases for creating users
 testUsers := []map[string]interface{}{
 {"name": "", "email": "test@example.com"}, // Empty name
 {"name": "Zhang San", "email": ""}, // Empty email
 {"name": "Li Si", "email": "duplicate@example.com"}, // Duplicate email
 {"name": "Wang Wu", "email": "valid@example.com"}, // Normal case
 }

 for i, user := range testUsers {
 fmt.Printf("Test %d - Creating user %+v: ", i+1, user)
 err := repo.CreateUser(user)
 if err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Creation successful\n")
 }
 }

 // Test querying users
 fmt.Println("\n=== Query User Test ===")
 testEmails := []string{
 "", // Empty email
 "notfound@example.com", // User does not exist
 "valid@example.com", // Normal query
 }

 for _, email := range testEmails {
 fmt.Printf("Querying email '%s': ", email)
 user, err := repo.FindUserByEmail(email)
 if err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Found user: %+v\n", user)
 }
 }
}

func main() {
 demonstrateDatabaseErrors()

 // Transaction error handling example
 fmt.Println("\n=== Transaction Error Handling ===")

 simulateTransaction := func() error {
 // Begin transaction
 fmt.Println("Starting transaction...")

 // Step 1: Create user
 if err := errors.New("User creation failed"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Transaction step 1 failed: %v\n", err)
 return fmt.Errorf("Transaction rollback: User creation failed - %w", err)
 }

 // Step 2: Create user profile
 if err := errors.New("Profile creation failed"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ Transaction step 2 failed: %v\n", err)
 return fmt.Errorf("Transaction rollback: Profile creation failed - %w", err)
 }

 // Step 3: Send welcome email
 if err := errors.New("Email sending failed"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("⚠️ Non-critical step failed: %v\n", err)
 // Non-critical step failure, can choose to continue
 }

 fmt.Println("✅ Transaction committed successfully")
 return nil
 }

 if err := simulateTransaction(); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("Transaction ultimately failed: %v\n", err)
 }
}

Execution result:

=== Database Error Handling Demonstration ===
Test 1 - Creating user map[email:test@example.com name:]: ❌ Username cannot be empty
Test 2 - Creating user map[email: name:Zhang San]: ❌ Email cannot be empty
Test 3 - Creating user map[email:duplicate@example.com name:Li Si]: ❌ Email address already exists: Unique constraint violation
Test 4 - Creating user map[email:valid@example.com name:Wang Wu]: ✅ Creation successful

=== Query User Test ===
Querying email '': ❌ Email address cannot be empty
Querying email 'notfound@example.com': ❌ User does not exist
Querying email 'valid@example.com': ✅ Found user: map[email:valid@example.com id:1 name:Zhang San]

=== Transaction Error Handling ===
Starting transaction...
❌ Transaction step 1 failed: User creation failed
Transaction ultimately failed: Transaction rollback: User creation failed - User creation failed

6. Error Handling Best Practices

6.1 Error Handling Principles 

package main

import (
 "errors"
 "fmt"
 "log"
)

// Good error handling practices

// 1. Handle errors promptly, don't delay
func goodErrorHandling1() error {
 data, err := readConfig()
 if err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("Failed to read config: %w", err) // Handle immediately
 }

 if err := validateConfig(data); err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("Config validation failed: %w", err) // Handle immediately
 }

 return nil
}

// 2. Provide meaningful error information
func goodErrorHandling2(filename string) error {
 file, err := openFile(filename)
 if err != nil {
 // Good error information includes context
 return fmt.Errorf("Unable to open config file '%s': %w", filename, err)
 }
 defer file.Close()
 return nil
}

// 3. Distinguish different types of errors
func goodErrorHandling3(userID string) error {
 user, err := findUser(userID)
 if err != nil {
 // Take different actions based on error type
 switch {
 case errors.Is(err, ErrUserNotFound):
 return fmt.Errorf("User does not exist, please register first")
 case errors.Is(err, ErrDatabaseDown):
 return fmt.Errorf("System maintenance, please try again later")
 default:
 return fmt.Errorf("Failed to get user info: %w", err)
 }
 }

 if !user.IsActive {
 return fmt.Errorf("User account has been disabled")
 }

 return nil
}

// 4. Log errors but don't expose internal details
func goodErrorHandling4() {
 if err := sensitiveOperation(); err != nil {
 // Log detailed error to logs
 log.Printf("Sensitive operation failed (internal error): %+v", err)
 // Return generic error to user
 fmt.Println("Operation failed, please contact administrator")
 }
}

// Simulate functions
func readConfig() (interface{}, error) {
 return nil, errors.New("File does not exist")
}

func validateConfig(data interface{}) error {
 return errors.New("Config format error")
}

func openFile(filename string) (interface{}, error) {
 return nil, errors.New("Permission denied")
}

var (
 ErrUserNotFound = errors.New("User does not exist")
 ErrDatabaseDown = errors.New("Database down")
)

func findUser(userID string) (interface{}, error) {
 return nil, ErrUserNotFound
}

type User struct {
 IsActive bool
}

func sensitiveOperation() error {
 return errors.New("Internal database credentials leaked")
}

// Bad error handling practices

// 1. Ignoring errors
func badErrorHandling1() {
 data, _ := readConfig() // Error ignored
 processConfig(data) // May use nil data
}

// 2. Unclear error information
func badErrorHandling2(filename string) error {
 _, err := openFile(filename)
 if err != nil {
 return err // Error information too simple
 }
 return nil
}

// 3. Over-wrapping errors
func badErrorHandling3() error {
 err := lowLevelError()
 if err != nil {
 return fmt.Errorf("High-level error: %w",
 fmt.Errorf("Mid-level error: %w",
 fmt.Errorf("Low-level error: %w", err))) // Over-wrapping
 }
 return nil
}

func lowLevelError() error {
 return errors.New("Low-level error")
}

func processConfig(data interface{}) {
 // Process config
}

func main() {
 fmt.Println("=== Error Handling Best Practices ===")

 fmt.Println("Good practice examples:")
 if err := goodErrorHandling1(); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 if err := goodErrorHandling2("config.json"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 if err := goodErrorHandling3("user123"); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 }

 goodErrorHandling4()

 fmt.Println("\nBad practices to avoid:")
 fmt.Println("1. Ignoring errors may cause program crashes")
 fmt.Println("2. Unclear error information is difficult to debug")
 fmt.Println("3. Over-wrapping makes error chains overly complex")

 // Demonstrate error logging best practices
 fmt.Println("\n=== Error Logging Best Practices ===")

 logError := func(context string, err error) {
 // Development environment: detailed logs
 log.Printf("[DEBUG] %s failed: %+v", context, err)

 // Production environment: simplified logs
 log.Printf("[ERROR] %s failed, please check detailed logs", context)
 }

 // Simulate error recording
 sampleErr := fmt.Errorf("Database connection failed: %w",
 errors.New("Network timeout"))
 logError("User login", sampleErr)
}

Execution result:

=== Error Handling Best Practices ===
Good practice examples:
❌ Failed to read config: File does not exist
❌ Unable to open config file 'config.json': Permission denied
❌ User does not exist, please register first
Operation failed, please contact administrator

Bad practices to avoid:
1. Ignoring errors may cause program crashes
2. Unclear error information is difficult to debug
3. Over-wrapping makes error chains overly complex

=== Error Logging Best Practices ===
2024/01/15 15:30:45 [DEBUG] User login failed: Database connection failed: Network timeout
2024/01/15 15:30:45 [ERROR] User login failed, please check detailed logs

7. Summary

Go language’s error handling mechanism embodies its design philosophy of “simple, clear, practical”:

Core points:

  • Errors are values and should be explicitly checked and handled
  • Use error interface to unify error representation
  • Modern error handling features provided through errors package
  • Reasonable use of error wrapping and context information

Best practices:

  1. Handle promptly: Handle errors immediately when discovered, don’t delay
  2. Provide context: Error information should include sufficient context
  3. Distinguish error types: Take different handling strategies based on error types
  4. Log detailed information: Record detailed errors internally, return appropriate information externally
  5. Avoid error ignoring: Unless truly ignorable, all errors should be handled

Modern developments:

  • Go 1.13+ introduced new error wrapping and checking features
  • errors.Is() and errors.As() provide better error checking capabilities
  • fmt.Errorf()’s %w verb supports error wrapping

Good error handling not only improves program robustness but also greatly enhances user experience and system maintainability. In actual development, appropriate error handling strategies should be chosen based on specific scenarios.

item.title: Golang Learning Journey [Part 11: Interface]
item.description:
1. What is Interface

Interface is the core mechanism for implementing abstraction and polymorphism in Go language. If structs solve the problem of “what data is”, then interfaces solve the problem of “what can be done”. Interfaces define a set of method signatures, and any type that implements these methods “implements” the interface.

1.1 Basic Concepts of Interface

Let’s understand interfaces through a real-life example:

Real scenario:

  • USB interface: Defines the standard for data transmission
  • Any device that conforms to USB standards (USB drives, mice, keyboards) can be plugged in and used
  • We don’t need to care what specific device it is, as long as it conforms to USB standards

Programming scenario:

  • Interface defines method signatures (what can be done)
  • Any type that implements these methods automatically implements the interface
  • We can program to interfaces rather than caring about specific implementations

1.2 Value and Significance of Interfaces

Main roles of interfaces:

  1. Decoupling: Separate interface definition from specific implementation
  2. Polymorphism: Same interface can have multiple implementations
  3. Abstraction: Hide specific implementation details
  4. Extensibility: Easy to add new implementations
  5. Test-friendly: Facilitate writing mock tests

2. Basic Interface Syntax

2.1 Interface Definition Syntax 

type InterfaceName interface {
 MethodName1(ParameterList) ReturnList
 MethodName2(ParameterList) ReturnList
 // ... More methods
}

2.2 Simple Interface Example 

package main

import "fmt"

// Define animal interface
type Animal interface {
 Speak() string // Speaking method
 Move() string // Moving method
 GetAge() int // Get age method
}

// Dog implementation
type Dog struct {
 Name string
 Age int
}

func (d Dog) Speak() string {
 return "Woof"
}

func (d Dog) Move() string {
 return "Running"
}

func (d Dog) GetAge() int {
 return d.Age
}

// Cat implementation
type Cat struct {
 Name string
 Age int
}

func (c Cat) Speak() string {
 return "Meow"
}

func (c Cat) Move() string {
 return "Crawling"
}

func (c Cat) GetAge() int {
 return c.Age
}

// Bird implementation
type Bird struct {
 Species string
 Age int
}

func (b Bird) Speak() string {
 return "Chirp"
}

func (b Bird) Move() string {
 return "Flying"
}

func (b Bird) GetAge() int {
 return b.Age
}

// Function using interface
func MakeAnimalSpeak(animal Animal) {
 fmt.Printf("Animal speaks: %s\n", animal.Speak())
}

func ShowAnimalMove(animal Animal) {
 fmt.Printf("Animal moves by: %s\n", animal.Move())
}

func main() {
 // Create different types of animals
 dog := Dog{Name: "Wang Cai", Age: 3}
 cat := Cat{Name: "Mi Mi", Age: 2}
 bird := Bird{Species: "Parrot", Age: 1}

 // All can be used as Animal interface
 animals := []Animal{dog, cat, bird}

 fmt.Println("=== Animal Performance ===")
 for i, animal := range animals {
 fmt.Printf("Animal %d:\n", i+1)
 MakeAnimalSpeak(animal)
 ShowAnimalMove(animal)
 fmt.Printf("Age: %d years\n\n", animal.GetAge())
 }

 // Direct use of specific types
 fmt.Println("=== Specific Type Calls ===")
 fmt.Printf("Dog speaks: %s\n", dog.Speak())
 fmt.Printf("Cat moves: %s\n", cat.Move())
 fmt.Printf("Bird age: %d\n", bird.GetAge())
}

Execution result:

=== Animal Performance ===
Animal 1:
Animal speaks: Woof
Animal moves by: Running
Age: 3 years

Animal 2:
Animal speaks: Meow
Animal moves by: Crawling
Age: 2 years

Animal 3:
Animal speaks: Chirp
Animal moves by: Flying
Age: 1 years

=== Specific Type Calls ===
Dog speaks: Woof
Cat moves: Crawling
Bird age: 1

3. Interface Implementation Mechanism

3.1 Implicit Implementation

Go language’s interface implementation is implicit and doesn’t require explicit declaration:

package main

import "fmt"

// Define interfaces
type Writer interface {
 Write(data string) (int, error)
}

type Reader interface {
 Read() (string, error)
}

// File type implementation
type File struct {
 Name string
 Content string
 Pos int
}

func (f *File) Write(data string) (int, error) {
 f.Content += data
 return len(data), nil
}

func (f *File) Read() (string, error) {
 if f.Pos >= len(f.Content) {
 return "", fmt.Errorf("Reading ended")
 }
 result := f.Content[f.Pos:]
 f.Pos = len(f.Content)
 return result, nil
}

// Network connection type implementation
type NetworkConnection struct {
 Address string
 Buffer string
}

func (nc *NetworkConnection) Write(data string) (int, error) {
 nc.Buffer += data
 fmt.Printf("Network sending to %s: %s\n", nc.Address, data)
 return len(data), nil
}

func (nc *NetworkConnection) Read() (string, error) {
 if nc.Buffer == "" {
 return "", fmt.Errorf("Buffer is empty")
 }
 result := nc.Buffer
 nc.Buffer = ""
 return result, nil
}

// Generic function using interfaces
func ProcessData(w Writer, r Reader, data string) {
 // Write data
 n, err := w.Write(data)
 if err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("Write error: %v\n", err)
 return
 }
 fmt.Printf("Successfully wrote %d characters\n", n)

 // Read data
 content, err := r.Read()
 if err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("Read error: %v\n", err)
 return
 }
 fmt.Printf("Read content: %s\n", content)
}

func main() {
 // File operations
 file := &File{Name: "test.txt"}
 fmt.Println("=== File Operations ===")
 ProcessData(file, file, "Hello, File!")

 // Network operations
 conn := &NetworkConnection{Address: "192.168.1.1:8080"}
 fmt.Println("\n=== Network Operations ===")
 ProcessData(conn, conn, "Hello, Network!")

 // Mixed use
 fmt.Println("\n=== Mixed Operations ===")
 ProcessData(file, conn, "Mixed operation test")
}

Execution result:

=== File Operations ===
Successfully wrote 11 characters
Read content: Hello, File!

=== Network Operations ===
Network sending to 192.168.1.1:8080: Hello, Network!
Successfully wrote 15 characters
Read content: Hello, Network!

=== Mixed Operations ===
Successfully wrote 21 characters
Network sending to 192.168.1.1:8080: Hello, File!
Read content: Hello, File!

3.2 Internal Structure of Interface Values 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
 "reflect"
 "unsafe"
)

type Speaker interface {
 Speak() string
}

type Dog struct {
 Name string
}

func (d Dog) Speak() string {
 return "Woof, I'm " + d.Name
}

type Cat struct {
 Name string
}

func (c Cat) Speak() string {
 return "Meow, I'm " + c.Name
}

func InspectInterface(i interface{}) {
 v := reflect.ValueOf(i)
 fmt.Printf("Type: %T\n", i)
 fmt.Printf("Value: %v\n", i)
 fmt.Printf("Is nil: %t\n", i == nil)

 if v.Kind() == reflect.Interface {
 elem := v.Elem()
 fmt.Printf("Dynamic type: %T\n", elem.Interface())
 fmt.Printf("Dynamic value: %v\n", elem.Interface())
 }
 fmt.Println("---")
}

func main() {
 // nil interface value
 var speaker1 Speaker
 fmt.Println("1. nil interface value:")
 InspectInterface(speaker1)

 // Concrete type assignment
 dog := Dog{Name: "Wang Cai"}
 speaker1 = dog
 fmt.Println("2. After assigning Dog:")
 InspectInterface(speaker1)

 // Different type assignment
 cat := Cat{Name: "Mi Mi"}
 speaker1 = cat
 fmt.Println("3. After assigning Cat:")
 InspectInterface(speaker1)

 // Interface slice
 speakers := []Speaker{dog, cat}
 fmt.Println("4. Interface slice:")
 for i, s := range speakers {
 fmt.Printf("Index %d: %T - %s\n", i, s, s.Speak())
 }
}

Execution result:

1. nil interface value:
Type: <nil>
Value: <nil>
Is nil: true
---
2. After assigning Dog:
Type: main.Dog
Value: {Wang Cai}
Is nil: false
Dynamic type: main.Dog
Dynamic value: {Wang Cai}
---
3. After assigning Cat:
Type: main.Cat
Value: {Mi Mi}
Is nil: false
Dynamic type: main.Cat
Dynamic value: {Mi Mi}
---
4. Interface slice:
Index 0: main.Dog - Woof, I'm Wang Cai
Index 1: main.Cat - Meow, I'm Mi Mi

4. Common Built-in Interfaces

4.1 error Interface 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
)

// error interface definition
// type error interface {
// Error() string
// }

// Custom error type
type ValidationError struct {
 Field string
 Message string
}

func (e ValidationError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Validation error - Field: %s, Message: %s", e.Field, e.Message)
}

type NetworkError struct {
 Code int
 Message string
}

func (e NetworkError) Error() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Network error[%d]: %s", e.Code, e.Message)
}

// Function returning error
func ValidateAge(age int) error {
 if age < 0 {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "age",
 Message: "Age cannot be negative",
 }
 }
 if age > 150 {
 return ValidationError{
 Field: "age",
 Message: "Age cannot exceed 150 years",
 }
 }
 return nil // No error
}

func ConnectToServer(url string) error {
 if url == "" {
 return NetworkError{
 Code: 400,
 Message: "URL cannot be empty",
 }
 }
 if url == "timeout.com" {
 return NetworkError{
 Code: 504,
 Message: "Connection timeout",
 }
 }
 return nil // Connection successful
}

func main() {
 // Test validation errors
 ages := []int{-5, 25, 200}
 for _, age := range ages {
 fmt.Printf("Validating age %d: ", age)
 if err := ValidateAge(age); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Validation passed\n")
 }
 }

 // Test network errors
 urls := []string{"", "timeout.com", "google.com"}
 fmt.Println("\n=== Network Connection Test ===")
 for _, url := range urls {
 fmt.Printf("Connecting to %s: ", url)
 if err := ConnectToServer(url); err != nil {
 fmt.Printf("❌ %v\n", err)
 } else {
 fmt.Printf("✅ Connection successful\n")
 }
 }

 // Error type assertion
 fmt.Println("\n=== Error Type Analysis ===")
 err := ValidateAge(-1)
 if err != nil {
 if validationErr, ok := err.(ValidationError); ok {
 fmt.Printf("This is a validation error: field=%s, message=%s\n",
 validationErr.Field, validationErr.Message)
 }
 }
}

Execution result:

Validating age -5: ❌ Validation error - Field: age, Message: Age cannot be negative
Validating age 25: ✅ Validation passed
Validating age 200: ❌ Validation error - Field: age, Message: Age cannot exceed 150 years

=== Network Connection Test ===
Connecting to : ❌ Network error[400]: URL cannot be empty
Connecting to timeout.com: ❌ Network error[504]: Connection timeout
Connecting to google.com: ✅ Connection successful

=== Error Type Analysis ===
This is a validation error: field=age, message=Age cannot be negative

4.2 Stringer Interface 

package main

import (
 "fmt"
)

// Stringer interface definition
// type Stringer interface {
// String() string
// }

type Person struct {
 Name string
 Age int
 City string
}

func (p Person) String() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Name: %s, Age: %d years, From: %s", p.Name, p.Age, p.City)
}

type Product struct {
 Name string
 Price float64
 Stock int
}

func (p Product) String() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("Product: %s, Price: ¥%.2f, Stock: %d pieces", p.Name, p.Price, p.Stock)
}

type Point struct {
 X, Y int
}

func (p Point) String() string {
 return fmt.Sprintf("(%d, %d)", p.X, p.Y)
}

func main() {
 // Create various objects
 person := Person{Name: "Zhang San", Age: 25, City: "Beijing"}
 product := Product{Name: "iPhone 15", Price: 5999.00, Stock: 100}
 point := Point{X: 10, Y: 20}

 // Direct printing will automatically call String() method
 fmt.Println("=== Automatic String() Method Call ===")
 fmt.Println(person)
 fmt.Println(product)
 fmt.Println(point)

 // Explicit String() method call
 fmt.Println("\n=== Explicit String() Method Call ===")
 fmt.Println("Person string representation: ", person.String())
 fmt.Println("Product string representation: ", product.String())
 fmt.Println("Point string representation: ", point.String())

 // Usage in formatting
 fmt.Println("\n=== Formatted Output ===")
 fmt.Printf("Personal info: %s\n", person)
 fmt.Printf("Product info: %s\n", product)
 fmt.Printf("Coordinate info: %s\n", point)

 // Slices and maps
 people := []Person{
 {Name: "Li Si", Age: 30, City: "Shanghai"},
 {Name: "Wang Wu", Age: 28, City: "Guangzhou"},
 }

 fmt.Println("\n=== Object Slice ===")
 fmt.Println(people)
}

Execution result:

=== Automatic String() Method Call ===
Name: Zhang San, Age: 25 years, From: Beijing
Product: iPhone 15, Price: ¥5999.00, Stock: 100 pieces
(10, 20)

=== Explicit String() Method Call ===
Person string representation: Name: Zhang San, Age: 25 years, From: Beijing
Product string representation: Product: iPhone 15, Price: ¥5999.00, Stock: 100 pieces
Point string representation: (10, 20)

=== Formatted Output ===
Personal info: Name: Zhang San, Age: 25 years, From: Beijing
Product info: Product: iPhone 15, Price: ¥5999.00, Stock: 100 pieces
Coordinate info: (10, 20)

=== Object Slice ===
[{Li Si 30 Shanghai} {Wang Wu 28 Guangzhou}]

5. Interface Composition and Nesting

5.1 Interface Composition 

package main

import "fmt"

// Basic interfaces
type Reader interface {
 Read() (string, error)
}

type Writer interface {
 Write(data string) (int, error)
}

type Closer interface {
 Close() error
}

// Composite interfaces
type ReadWriter interface {
 Reader // Embed Reader interface
 Writer // Embed Writer interface
}

type ReadWriteCloser interface {
 Reader // Reading functionality
 Writer // Writing functionality
 Closer // Closing functionality
}

// Concrete implementation
type File struct {
 Name string
 Content string
 Closed bool
}

func (f *File) Read() (string, error) {
 if f.Closed {
 return "", fmt.Errorf("File is closed")
 }
 return f.Content, nil
}

func (f *File) Write(data string) (int, error) {
 if f.Closed {
 return 0, fmt.Errorf("File is closed")
 }
 f.Content += data
